large-landmarks-description: Find your way from the Arc de Triomphe to the Eiffel Tower, without using a map!
large-landmarks-trivia-1: Commissioned by Napoleon in 1806 after his victory at Austerlitz, the Arc de Triomphe honours those who fought and died for France during the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars. It took 30 years to complete and now stands as a symbol of national pride, with the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier beneath it, which was added in 1921 to commemorate those who died in the First World War.
large-landmarks-trivia-2: The Eiffel Tower, completed in 1889, was initially criticised for its design but has since become an iconic symbol of Paris. Standing 330 metres tall, it was the world’s tallest man-made structure until the Chrysler Building was completed in New York in 1930. Designed by engineer Gustave Eiffel, the tower was originally intended to be temporary, but its usefulness for scientific research and telecommunications led to its permanent status. Today, it’s one of the most visited monuments in the world, attracting millions of tourists each year.
lets-meet-description: Make the Street Views meet by reaching the same point with the same orientation!
lets-meet-trivia-1: You are looking at Lac de Naussac, on the edge of Langogne in the Lozère department of Occitanie. A tranquil reservoir surrounded by stunning natural scenery, Lac de Naussac is a popular destination for outdoor activities like fishing, hiking and water sports.
lets-meet-trivia-2: You are in the centre of Langogne, a small town in the Lozère department of Occitanie, known for its historic buildings and central market square. The town has a rich heritage, with its origins dating back to the medieval period. It serves as a local hub for the surrounding rural communities and offers a quiet, traditional atmosphere.
its-an-emergency-description: Quick! We need to find a pharmacy to buy some cough medicine! Find one as quickly as possible.
its-an-emergency-trivia-1: Note: Pharmacies are marked with a green cross.
its-an-emergency-trivia-2: Bar-le-Duc is a historic town located in the Grand Est region of northeastern France. Known for its beautiful Renaissance architecture and scenic location along the Ornain River, Bar-le-Duc is famous for its traditional jelly, made from local fruits, and offers a glimpse into France's past with landmarks such as the Château de Bar-le-Duc and the Saint-Étienne Church.

list-webcams.title: Port de la Santé, Villefranche-sur-Mer, Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur
list-webcams.description: Port de la Santé is a small, scenic harbour in Villefranche-sur-Mer, in the region of Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur. Nestled along the Mediterranean coast, it’s known for colourful boats, cruise tenders and a picturesque waterfront.

list-webcams.title: La Plagne-Tarentaise, Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes
list-webcams.description: La Plagne-Tarentaise is a scenic alpine area in the French Alps, known for its snowy slopes, ski resorts and mountain views. It's part of the popular Paradiski region, attracting skiers and winter sports lovers from around the world.

list-webcams.title: Munster, Grand Est
list-webcams.description: Munster is a charming town in the Grand Est region of France, nestled in the Vosges mountains. Known for its traditional Alsatian architecture and famous Munster cheese, it offers a peaceful setting surrounded by rolling hills and lush greenery.

list-webcams.title: Port des Sables d’Olonne, Pays de la Loire
list-webcams.description: Port des Sables-d’Olonne is a vibrant harbour on the Atlantic coast, renowned for its fishing fleet and the marina — the starting point of the Vendée Globe yacht race. The port's entrance is marked by several lighthouses while the surrounding area offers a lively waterfront with cafés and promenades.

list-webcams.title: Saint-Malo, Brittany
list-webcams.description: Saint-Malo, located in Brittany, is a historic port city known for its stunning walled old town and picturesque harbour. The city has a rich maritime history, and its port is a hub for both commercial and leisure vessels. Saint-Malo is particularly popular for its beaches, seafood and striking coastline.

list-webcams.title: Font-Romeu-Odeillo-Via, Occitanie
list-webcams.description: Font-Romeu-Odeillo-Via is a mountain town in the French Pyrenees, renowned for its ski resort, sunny climate and altitude training centre. It also hosts one of the world’s largest solar furnaces, the Four Solaire d’Odeillo.
